data.text: Why Should I Use Garmin or Wahoo Instead of my iPhone?

Hope you'll pardon another newbie question...I am a modestly experienced rider, but have yet to do any multi-day touring trips, though have a few planned in the next 2 months and am excited about them. My question is about the cockpit and iPhone vs a Garmin or Wahoo product. In all my riding thus far, I am happy with my iPhone mounted on my quadlock using ridewithgps app and my varia. What additional functionality would a Garmin Edge or Wahoo Element give me? Thanks for any input.....
Really just battery life & sparing battery drain on your phone.
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: i agree. Also maybe in rainy days you will avoid humidity problems with your phone. But really I don't think they are worth it. At least not if you are not touring in the middle of nowhere with no human life for miles and miles.
data.author: Parsa Jazni

data.text: I use an android phone in airplane mode (to save battery - can turn on cell service when needed, also use this as a wireless hotspot) running offline mapping /GPS software- OSMAnd & a few alternates for navigation & POIs (ACA‚Äôs bicycle route navigator, Komoot, maps.me, ride with GPS, Mapy.cz, google maps offline) & a Hammerhead Karoo 2. I like the large screen on the phone for maps. The phone with cell service toggled on also serves for Warmshowers & other services en route. Tho a diehard Apple aficionado, android excels for the navigation apps.
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: A Loksac bag or Topeak phone dry bag keeps the phone dry in rain. I carry a few powerbanks to recharge devices & keep these charged with voltaic systems solar charging systems. (I ride a recumbent trike, so can carry massive amounts of kulch).

My knockoff Fitbit tells me if my heart rate gets too high. I have paper written turns in my handlebar bag if needed. It works better for me

data.text: yup, good old simple bike computer for distance and average speed, batteries last for months... and paper map... relying on Garmin or phone triggers a whole chain of things that become weight and risks... To charge it you need a power bank.. to charge the power bank you need a generator hub... To get the generator hub you need to buy it and build a wheel around it....

data.text: I tried using my phone to record my rides and it killed the battery before I was done every time (and I always had data turned off). I bought a Garmin 810 then, in 2013, because it had mapping functionality and my phone would still have some juice if I actually needed it for anything. I just replaced the Garmin with an 830 as I‚Äôm happy with my system.

data.text: I added the Garmin 1030 Plus as I was killing iPhone batteries too fast. Both have their place.

data.text: I have a cheap phone with limited apps for talk/text. I have my old Samsung for camera, nav apps and music. It saves me from burning through batteries. I have battery banks that also help. The $$ bike computers are greeat if you need them for a specific reason, but otherwise they are not any more "useful" than a phone app.

data.text: The battery issue is what made me mostly navigate with a Wahoo ELEMNT roam. A few times when I really needed my cell in an emergency I was low on battery. Bad feeling.

data.text: Nice topic. People used to cycle far without the electronics stuff. But GPS navigation is so nice. I have tried numerous things with my phone to navigate cycling without a map, does not work well, can't see the screen or hear the instructions. Tried blootooth ear buds, tried special holder bag on top tube, just does not work for me. My Garmin watch is fantastic, but for general use, but serious cycling it probably just won't be as good as a cycling specific unit.

data.text: Battery life has been the biggest reason I stopped navigating with iPhone. And charging the phone is problematic in the rain. Also the touch screen is hard to operate in the rain and kind of goes berserk. data.text: I use an iPhone and yes, the battery life sucks. I bought a SKS phone holder and storage compartment when we traveled in Europe. Worked so well I got one for my road bike.
